data.text: Contents
Introduction
This policy describes how the Trust and its staff will manage media and related enquiries, proactive media relations and the duties and responsibilities associated.

All media interest must be handled in a way that meets our legal duties to patients, staff and visitors. In an NHS organisation, patient confidentiality and the requirement to seek informed consent before the release of any information or photographs, place additional responsibilities on us all.
The communications team plays the lead role in helping the Trust to manage its reputation, seeking to ensure that any media coverage we receive is accurate, fair and, wherever possible, positive.

The communications team provides a 24 hour on call service, liaising with site managers and executive director on call out-of-hours as required, to ensure that we are able to provide the media with fast and accurate responses to their enquiries, whilst safeguarding patient confidentiality and privacy.
Scope

This policy sets out the Trust's arrangements for dealing with media enquiries and what staff should do if they are contacted by the media, in their capacity as a Trust employee, as an expert, or as a representative of another body such as a professional organisation, a trade union or a charity.

The policy applies to all staff and volunteers employed by or working on behalf of the Trust. It is the responsibility of all senior managers to ensure that staff members are fully aware of the hospital's policy when dealing with any media enquiries.

data.text: Duties
Duties of Committees within the Trust
Site leadership teams and Executive Directors are responsible for providing assurance to the Trust board that media relations and organisational reputation are appropriately managed.
Chief executive is responsible for:
Supporting communication and engagement activities, including acting as spokesperson to staff and other stakeholders. Having a visible presence to patients and their families.
Site leadership teams and Executive Directors have an on-going day-to-day responsibility for delivering the organisation's strategic objectives which includes the elements contained in this policy.

These are also alerted when a media enquiry related to their area or site comes in and help provide best contacts. The appropriate director will also sign off media statement before they are sent out.
The communications department will:
Have the lead responsibility for managing both reactive and proactive media relations for the Trust and policing this policy.
Log and respond to all media enquiries and requests for proactive interviews within the negotiated deadline.
Be the authorised primary contact between the Trust and the media and seek, assess and review information from Trust staff in doing so.
Provide advice and support to staff, patients and governors in relations with the media.

Cooperate with the media wherever possible. However, there are circumstances when this might be inappropriate, for example, for legal reasons where this might prejudice a police investigation or legal proceedings. The communications department will advise on these situations, and work closely with the Trust's legal team when necessary or with other agencies including the police and emergency services or public health advisers.

In the event of a member of staff has agreed to be interviewed, filmed or photographed, following liaison with and agreement of the communications department, it will make all the necessary arrangements, which includes informing security and making sure appropriate consent has been sought and/or legal agreements are in place.
Heads of Service/Managers are responsible for:
Ensuring messages from the Communications Team and the Executive Team are cascaded in a meaningful and timely manner to their teams.
Passing on information to colleagues without access to electronic communication methods.
All staff have a responsibility to:
Listen to and respond to feedback from patients, carers and families and actively assist them to access both health information and healthcare services.
Keep up to date with the latest communication messages and provide feedback as appropriate.
Ensure that contact with stakeholders is positive, representing the organisation in line with its values and reporting and acting on stakeholder feedback.
Communications principles
The Trust's communications strategy lists the following principles which underpin its approach to communications:
Simple, clear and concise
Honest in the use and sharing of information by ensuring the quality of its work and published information is accurate
Respectful of privacy, dignity and confidentiality
Accessible to all members of the public, members, staff, stakeholders, users, potential users, their carers and families
Relevant and targeted to the audience(s) by recognising their particular requirements and interests and the different communication needs of diverse communities
Timely and regular, with publications and announcements following an agreed schedule
Reflective of the Trust's corporate objectives and communications priorities
In keeping with both the spirit and requirements of the NHS Constitution
Media contact
All media enquiries must be promptly referred to the media team on 01702  during normal working hours or via the switchboard out-of-hours.
Any enquiry or contact which staff believe may be a media enquiry should be promptly referred to the communications department.

Regulation 8 of the Independent Press Standards Organisation (IPSO), Editors Code of Conduct (March 2015) states the following: “journalists or photographers making enquiries at hospitals or similar institutions must identify themselves to a responsible executive and obtain permission before entering non-public areas or similar institutions to pursue enquiries.”

While on site, members of the media should carry identification and be able to produce this on request. Staff members should challenge any person claiming to be from the media if they state they have clearance to be on site, and are not chaperoned by a recognised member of staff.
Staff should not attempt to answer any questions to the media unless they have been authorised to do so by the communications department.
Staff should contact the communications department immediately if they have received or forwarded a media enquiry regardless of whether the enquirer intends to contact the communications department.
Staff are authorised to discuss any matters with the communications department to help them manage media enquiries.

Staff can contact the communications department at any time for advice and guidance on media relations. Only urgent matters which require resolution before 9am on the next working day will be handled out-of-hours.
Staff seeking to contact the media, generate interest, promote an issue or publicise a development must seek advice and guidance from the communications department first.

Patients who seek or are subject to media interest should be instructed to contact the communications department so that they may be advised and assisted in their media contact and be aware of what the Trust will and will not be able to support.
Staff who have media contact in relation to activity unrelated to their work should advise the communications department in case the Trust receives enquiries.

Staff may sometimes be contacted to provide expert comment or advice in their professional capacity. This is entirely appropriate, and staff are entitled to provide this comment or advice provided it is unrelated to Trust business and activities. However, the communications department must be informed in case the Trust receives resultant enquiries. The procedure is documented at Appendix one.

The governance team will include the communications department in all Trust responses to requests for information under the Freedom of Information Act  from media outlets. This will ensure the communications department are aware of any potential media coverage.
Celebrity/VIP visits
The communications team co-ordinate all VIP/celebrity visits to the Trust (this includes Royal visits and visits/official openings from MPs, celebrities and sports people).
A member of the communications team will attend all such visits.

The number of people visiting wards will be limited to six people per group. Requests for additional visitors to the ward will be at the discretion of the ward manager. This is to ensure the wards are not overcrowded and to keep disruption to other patients and their families to a minimum.
General advice on reactive media relations
If a staff member is contacted directly, journalists will not be surprised if you direct them to the communications team as a first point of contact - this is usual practice.
Media enquiries need to be responded to quickly, sometimes within the hour. During a major incident or with significant breaking news the response times can be faster.
Some enquiries might involve other hospitals, parts of the NHS, emergency services or local government agencies and the communications department will co- ordinate with them as appropriate.
In some situations, such as a major incident, the Trust may not be the lead organisation, and it will be supporting the police, fire, ambulance, coastguard or social services in their response.
In all of these situations the communications department will coordinate the Trust's response.
Patient confidentiality and consent for media activity including
photography and film

All NHS staff have a duty to protect patient confidentiality and privacy. This requirement is paramount, and no information about a patient, including their presence in the hospital, may be disclosed to non-authorised staff without their informed consent. The communications team are authorised officers of the Trust in these circumstances to see and discuss patient confidential information.

Very occasionally if a patient is incapacitated, information can only be disclosed if this would be in the best interests of the patient. Relatives and carers would be consulted as part of the trust's decision about whether information should be released. Similarly, there may be rare occasions when the police request that no information is disclosed, irrespective of what the patient or relatives wish.

Consent is usually sought by the clinical staff caring for a patient, as they have established a relationship with the patient and/or their relatives. The communications department may be involved in this process, and will usually advise on the information that it would be appropriate to release. The clinical staff caring for the patient must make a record in the patient's medical and nursing or midwifery notes of what has been agreed.
The communications team may also advise the patient and/or their relatives on the media interest which has been received, and on any handling issues.

Where a patient or patient's representative has clearly surrendered his/her right to privacy and confidentiality by approaching the media and disclosing details of his/her condition or treatment, there may be a justifiable case for the Trust to consider releasing information to ensure factual accuracy. This will be decided by the communications department and a senior executive.
Written consent by any patient interviewed, photographed or filmed by the media, should always be given explicitly prior to any such event taking place.
A patient has the right to withdraw consent at any time up until the point at which the filming/interview/photography has taken place.

Where parental or guardian consent is secured for a minor, but the minor does not wish to participate in media activities, the wishes of the child will be upheld by the organisation over and above the pursuit of media activities by the parent or guardian.
Photographs, filming and audio recordings must not be used for any purpose other than that for which the original consent was granted, unless further patient consent is obtained.
When used internally, it is the responsibility of all staff to ensure that photographic images or footage are used only for the agreed purpose.

Where patients are being filmed/photographed in the background, verbal consent will be sufficient provided that patients are clear about how the footage will be used. However, wherever possible it is advised that a note of their name and time and place of verbal consent should be taken for future reference.
Film crews/photographers should be briefed prior to activity regarding the need for patient consent.

The communications team reserves the right to confirm, before broadcasting is permitted, that any footage broadcast does not breach confidentiality, and that the content of the broadcast fairly and accurately portrays the organisation and its activities.
A copy of the Trust Media Consent Forms is at Appendix Two.
Condition checks
A condition check is where the media will want to know the condition of a patient and updates on their condition. All condition checks can only be issued by the communications team.

The communications team has a system in place for dealing with these requests. This is to ensure that patient confidentiality is protected at all times. Condition checks will not be processed unless the correctly spelled name and date of birth of the patient is given.

Depending on the circumstances, this is another area where the police may need to be closely involved before any information can be released. If a case is referred to the HM Coroner, then it is for the coroner to establish the cause of death, and it is inappropriate for anyone to comment on this aspect in advance of the coroner's inquest taking place. All requests for information in relation to Inquests will be handled in conjunction with the Trust's legal team.
General advice on proactive media relations
It is part of the communication team's remit to identify opportunities for proactive media coverage. This includes:
key policy initiatives and service developments promoting innovative work
good practice
general ‘good news' stories

Colleagues are encouraged to discuss work they feel might interest the media with one of the communications team who will assess whether it is newsworthy and take appropriate action to try to generate media attention. All proactive media responses are authorised to take place in the following way:
The communication team works with relevant individuals to draft content, prepare interviews, or other material to be shared with the media.

The draft content is agreed by the individual, and the communications team. It is authorised for distribution by the head of communications and engagement, or in their absence, the senior manager with knowledge of the issue.
The communication team issue to media directly.
Interviews
Any interview requests need agreement from the communications team.
This could be an interview request for print, broadcast or social media. These are predominantly pre-recorded, but could be live for TV, radio or social media.

Where a request for interview has been made, the relevant individual must involve a member of the communications team in the planning of that interview and (where possible) a member of the communications team should be present during it to avoid any difficulties that may arise.
Major emergency

In the event of a major incident - for example, involving multiple casualties or large scale evacuation - the Trust will play a supporting role. Gold Command for such a major incident involving evacuation or casualties would be the Fire Service/Ambulance/Police depending on who takes control of the situation when responding to the media.
Major disease outbreaks are usually handled by Public Health England and CCGs.

A Trust specific issue could receive intense media interest, for example, a controversial consultation, critical report or a clinical issue. The level of media attention in this instance could approach that experienced during a major incident.
Brand
Our identity is important. It affects how people think and feel about the NHS. Our identity is largely shaped by what we do but our communications also play an important part in defining who we are.

Across all media and materials, our communications need to express and support our NHS values and principles. Through our communications, we also need to reassure people that NHS standards are being maintained.

The communications team remains responsible for the use of branding across the Trust and advice must be sort prior to publication of patient information, literature, signage, presentations or visual media in accordance with the Trust's corporate identity guidance.
Training requirements
There are no specific training requirements.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the relevant head of team. These will then be forwarded to the document control team for submission and approval by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the communications team of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary equality analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
